Name: David Walsh
All Critics Reviews: It might be best perhaps to describe Titanic as a sort of lowest common denominator. The film contains certain minimums necessary to draw an audience ... but its very blandness ... accounts for its great success.

Name: Mike Massie
All Critics Reviews: Stirring music and seamless special effects add to the thrills - it's just a shame it takes so long to get to that point.

Name: Geoff Brown
All Critics Reviews: For all the sluggish script and the enormous weight of the special effects, this movie behemoth still has the power to shake us rigid and and touch the soul.

Name: Nigel Andrews
All Critics Reviews: [The ending] is a masterpiece of popcorn tragedy: not deep, not sophisticated, barely even credible, but gut-clutching for those of us who have already lost the sensible use of our stomachs, as we would in any worthwhile fairground ride.

Name: Rachel Wagner
All Critics Reviews: It's the kind of movie that just doesn't come along that often.

Name: Sean Burns
All Critics Reviews: In recent years I've come around to thinking that a more nuanced version of the tale with better-rounded characters wouldn't resonate as powerfully as Cameron's shamelessly bold, sometimes silly strokes.

Name: David Baron
All Critics Reviews: See Titanic, then, for its success as an outrageous visual stunt -- a marvel of cinematic (and computer) sleight-of-hand. But don't go with any illusions that this soap opera on water is anything but a cartoon melodrama with fairy-tale leads.

Name: Quentin Curtis
All Critics Reviews: The movie is a ride, and not without the odd moment of corniness. But it's also about freedom and flight, bondage and stagnation. And most fittingly, as a memorial itself, it's about memory and the act of remembering.

Name: Duane Byrge
All Critics Reviews: No meager disaster movie, greased by generic formula and goosed by big-bucks technology... Titanic is one big, bruising movie that will appeal on different levels to different audiences.

Name: Hannah Ryan
All Critics Reviews: Titanic has deservedly cemented its place as one of the greatest movies of all time, as it manages to capture the wretchedness of historical tragedy while also skilfully enrapturing us with the dedication shown by one person to another...

Name: Matthew Sweet
All Critics Reviews: The dialogue may be unspeakable, but the film remains unsinkable.

Name: Jack Mathews
All Critics Reviews: Cameron's aim was to set the most intimate love story possible against one of the century's biggest tragedies, and he very nearly pulls it off. DiCaprio has a captivating presence in a role that might have been written for a young Clark Gable.

Name: Alissa Wilkinson
All Critics Reviews: What I can tell you, risking puns, is that it swept me off my feet almost from the get-go, a grand epic romance-disaster that reminded me, in the middle of my overstuffed-with-movies life, of what we mean when we talk about the power of cinema.

Name: Jason Bailey
All Critics Reviews: Sure, 'Titanic' may be corny, clumsy, and obvious-but the sincerity of its emotions and the power of its spectacle endure.

Name: Paul Tatara
All Critics Reviews: Cameron has devised a tender love story between Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio that serves as the main focus of Titanic's storyline, and it works beautifully.

Name: Dave Kehr
All Critics Reviews: If computer-generated special effects have overpowered human-generated drama, Cameron seizes that dangerously cold technology and recasts it as dream and delirium, profoundly human in its sources and longings.

Name: Desmond Ryan
All Critics Reviews: The execution is state-of-the-art and breathtaking. Titanic offers the full compass of courage and cowardice, and it stands as an achievement that truly is a night to remember at the movies.

Name: Maria Schneider
All Critics Reviews: Titanic provides an absorbing blend of historical fact and old-fashioned Hollywood tearjerking.

Name: Jay Boyar
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is indeed a ship of dreams. Climb aboard and bon voyage.

Name: Leah Rozen
All Critics Reviews: DiCaprio and Winslet both deliver star-making performances.

Name: Joe Holleman
All Critics Reviews: Take one of history's most compelling tragedies, tell it through the lives of two engaging young lovers and show it with some of the best-ever special effects and you have a dazzling, exciting movie that is also poignant and personal.

Name: Serena Donadoni
All Critics Reviews: It's a technically magnificent and emotionally wrenching experience.

Name: Rod Dreher
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is an awesome achievement, a traditional Hollywood epic that dazzles your eyes, breaks your heart and shivers your soul.

Name: Chris Knight
All Critics Reviews: DiCaprio manages a good mix of youthful bravado and nervous uncertainty... And Winslet shines as a willful rich girl who discovers her sensual side with this earthy urchin.

Name: Gene Siskel
All Critics Reviews: With his beatific, sweet, open face, DiCaprio gives us a rooting interest in hoping that someone important to us survives the wreck.

Name: Ben Kendrick
All Critics Reviews: Titanic 3D lacks creative synergy that could have been explored had the film been shot with 3D in mind but its easily the best example of post-conversion to date.

Name: R.L. Shaffer
All Critics Reviews: A staggering film, layered with melodramatic romance, tragedy, intensity and breathtaking production design.

Name: Jim Schembri
All Critics Reviews: Jack and Rose actually cause the Titanic to hit the iceberg. Watch closely.

Name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
All Critics Reviews: Director James Cameron takes one of his most beloved historical incidents and transforms it in to a McDonald's product...

Name: John J. Puccio
All Critics Reviews: While I admit the film does not impress me as much as it does most other people, there is no questioning its passion and excitement.

Name: Kelly Vance
All Critics Reviews: When the bolts start to pop and the water bursts the bulkheads and the ship's orchestra plays waltzes, writer-director Cameron achieves his vision grandly.

Name: Charlie Lyne
All Critics Reviews: The most breezy 194 minutes ever to grace the multiplex.

Name: Blake Howard
All Critics Reviews: The clunky dialogue, historical inaccuracy and overdose of Billy Zane in the opening stanza of the film is all but forgotten in one of the most emotionally affective, thrilling closing stanzas ever committed to celluloid.

Name: Linda Cook
All Critics Reviews: 'Titanic' is an epic that's see-worthy indeed. Directed/written/produced by James Cameron, its $200 million budget shows in its glorious effects, dazzling camera work and lavish sets, now, with the addition of Cameron's carefully crafted 3-D.

Name: Bruce Bennett
All Critics Reviews: Yes, it is time to return to the chilly North Atlantic to appreciate again James Cameron's glorious epic, for its scope, underappreciated script and perfect casting.

Name: Victoria Alexander
All Critics Reviews: Two spitting scenes in 3D and Jack Dawson loses his virginity. A second look indicates a cruel streak in the modern epic.

Name: Brett Michel
All Critics Reviews: Spoiler alert! The ship still sinks.

Name: Burl Burlingame
All Critics Reviews: It is, simply, a great film, a throwback to classic filmmaking, and more than that, an experience with unusual resonance to the world of today.

Name: Rob Humanick
All Critics Reviews: The kind of mass death spectacle Michael Bay is frequently accused (and often guilty) of partaking in is much better encapsulated in Titanic's final third.

Name: Dan Lybarger
All Critics Reviews: If you can get past the occasional Cameron clunker (Who can forget, "I'm the king of the world!") and Zane's almost amusingly over-the-top turn as Cal, Titanic still manages to make the tragedy seem more vivid than a statistic in a history book.

Name: Kevin A. Ranson
All Critics Reviews: Forget that we know how it all ends; it's the drama of dealing with eventuality that tells the real story here.

Name: Michelle Alexandria
All Critics Reviews: 15 years ago, I didn't let Titanic into my heart, now I get it. Movie is fantastic, but utterly fails as a 3D reissue.

Name: Matt Brunson
All Critics Reviews: While Titanic can't touch Cameron's true classics, The Terminator and Aliens, it's nevertheless better than Avatar, a surface treat that can't match the emotional pull of this alternately tragic, alternately triumphant tale of two star-crossed lovers.

Name: Lisa Giles-Keddie
All Critics Reviews: Simply one of 20th century cinema's greatest, old-fashioned love stories, full of still impressive effects (pre 3D) and decent, if theatrical acting ...

Name: Todd Gilchrist
All Critics Reviews: Titanic evidences the secret of his longtime success, a talent more impressive even than Cameron's technical prowess: his ability to find stories that tap into greater truths and deeper feelings.

Name: Ed Whitfield
All Critics Reviews: Forget women and children, what about truth and realism first?

Name: Cath Clarke
All Critics Reviews: We know the story ends badly but Cameron still sweeps us up in the romance between Kate Winslet's rebellious posh girl and DiCaprio's steerage kid.

Name: Norman Wilner
All Critics Reviews: Titanic still works brilliantly; it's a grand-scale studio epic with the heart of a romance and the pulse of an action movie. It's the only American film that rivals Gone With The Wind for both swoonery and production value.

Name: Alex Zane
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a movie that has to be seen on the big screen and will enchant a new generation of fans. A must-see 3D experience.

Name: David Sexton
All Critics Reviews: It has itself become, like the shipwreck, a cultural monument, only accreting value, not losing significance, as time goes by.

Name: Liverpool Echo Staff
All Critics Reviews: Cameron hasn't plugged any of the plot holes and some dialogue is still cheesy but now, just as in 1998, we forgive him a multitude of sins.

Name: Dana Stevens
All Critics Reviews: Cameron's three-hour disaster epic is a triumph of popular art -- of folk art, really.

Name: Rafer Guzman
All Critics Reviews: "Titanic" still amazes as the kind of massive, build-and-destroy production that few filmmakers have the ambition or budget to make.

Name: Ann Hornaday
All Critics Reviews: [Cameron] stages the sinking with a flawless sense of detail, pacing, import and dread.

Name: Alonso Duralde
All Critics Reviews: For all of its flaws, this movie works in the way that classic Hollywood movies do. It delivers.

Name: Christopher Tookey
All Critics Reviews: Its emotional impact lies in the fact it makes even the most blas of us feel what it must have been like to be on the sinking ship. And the film's underlying themes still have potency.

Name: Peter Bradshaw
All Critics Reviews: Only the snobbish or the obtuse could deny its ambition, verve and entertainment firepower.

Name: Joe Morgenstern
All Critics Reviews: This version has deepened and enriched a film that was already rich in emotions and remarkable for its depth of detail.

Name: Peter Travers
All Critics Reviews: How is Titanic in 3D? The answer is pretty damn dazzling.

Name: Gary Wolcott
All Critics Reviews: Those who've only seen it on video don't think the film is that big a deal. Trust me, it is. Even with the dragged out love story, Cameron's film is still mind-blowing.

Name: Brian Orndorf
All Critics Reviews: Time has been kind to the effort, exposing a strikingly constructed, sporadically numbskulled, exhaustively sentimental feature that sails smoothly with an unobtrusive 3D addition.

Name: Basia Cummings
All Critics Reviews: If you fancy indulging in pure, unadulterated silliness and spending a night in the '90s, this is a good bet. Otherwise...

Name: Rich Cline
All Critics Reviews: Reissued to tie in with the 100th anniversary of the Titanic's ill-fated maiden voyage, it's astonishing how timeless the film looks. And as a true classic, it doesn't lose our attention for a moment.

Name: Adrian Turner
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a sumptuous assault on the emotions, with a final hour that fully captures the horror and the freezing, paralysing fear of the moment.

Name: Michael Phillips
All Critics Reviews: Cameron is a genius at instilling narrative dread and designing a hokum-drenched fairy tale of a certain size.

Name: Drew McWeeny
All Critics Reviews: Like the film or don't like the film, there are very few filmmakers working now or ever who could have done what Cameron did here, no matter what resources they had.

Name: L. Thompson
All Critics Reviews: Near, far, wherever you are sitting in the theater, the newly revamped Titanic now has stuff coming out at you.

Name: Christy Lemire
All Critics Reviews: If any film should be redone in 3-D, it's "Titanic." And if any filmmaker should be the one doing the redoing, it's James Cameron.

Name: Henry Fitzherbert
All Critics Reviews: A timeless epic that gets me every time (yes, I needed my own life raft at the screening), the power of the storytelling and the performances by Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio grip throughout.

Name: Josh Forward
All Critics Reviews: It's so easy to see how this film that's still so enjoyable from start to end has become so iconic.

Name: Michael Simms
All Critics Reviews: Revisiting Titanic on the big screen, this time in impressive 3D, is a welcome reminder of solid blockbuster movie magic.

Name: Gary Thompson
All Critics Reviews: The central love story involving steerage passenger Leonardo DiCaprio and rich girl Kate Winslet has lost none of its luster - metaphorically speaking.

Name: Philip De Semlyen
All Critics Reviews: With a 3D conversion from the medium's pioneer-in-chief, Titanic is a big-screen romance that's every bit as epic as you remember.

Name: Graham Young
All Critics Reviews: It's for old-fashioned romantics who want to see a classic love story on the grandest scale.

Name: Simon Reynolds
All Critics Reviews: It's certainly a jaw-dropping big screen experience, even though the outcome is never in doubt. Just make sure you bolt for the door once Celine Dion's caterwauling kicks in.

Name: Matthew Turner
All Critics Reviews: A thoroughly gripping, emotionally powerful, genuinely thrilling and, yes, achingly romantic drama with jaw-dropping special effects and star-making performances from DiCaprio and Winslet.

Name: Rob Thomas
All Critics Reviews: "Titanic 3D" works because it's still "Titanic," a satisfying merger of newfangled effects and oldfangled melodrama. Judging by the wave of sniffles at the sneak preview screening I saw Tuesday night, it's a formula that endures 15 years later.

Name: R. Kurt Osenlund
All Critics Reviews: The re-release is keenly timed with the 100th anniversary of the actual sinking of the RMS Titanic, yet another factor to validate the 3D film's existence.

Name: Claudia Puig
All Critics Reviews: Sure, it's corny, but there's something endearing about the tale of young love and its earnest lack of irony.

Name: Emma Dibdin
All Critics Reviews: Leo and Kate give good doomed romance but it's the human horror of the collision, botched evacuation and final sinking that devastates most.

Name: Robbie Collin
All Critics Reviews: Cameron's detractors grouse about his use of scale and spectacle to invest archetypal, even clichd stories with an extra, unearned emotional significance. They're absolutely right, with one crucial caveat: there's absolutely nothing unearned about it.

Name: Joe Neumaier
All Critics Reviews: Like Kathy Bates' "unsinkable" Molly Brown, "Titanic" is unabashedly American: It's big, brash and sometimes gauche, yet also unapologetically earnest, amazing to look at and devoted to its own cause. And it knows how to win us over.

Name: Liam Lacey
All Critics Reviews: Overall, for a blockbuster movie about one great big thing hitting another great big thing, the new film shows distinctly upper-deck restraint.

Name: Peter Howell
All Critics Reviews: The letdown factor has been most keenly felt in conversions from 2D, but Titanic 3D shows how the ambition can be realized if the will and skill are there. We can only hope that other filmmakers follow Cameron's example.

Name: Nick Pinkerton
All Critics Reviews: But the power of Titanic didn't come from originality; it came from punching clichs across with a seldom-seen directness and sincerity that seemed pure of heart, "old-fashioned," or plain corny, depending on your perspective.

Name: Lou Lumenick
All Critics Reviews: James Cameron's spectacular new 3-D version of "Titanic'' is everything I'd hoped for, and more.

Name: Roger Moore
All Critics Reviews: I found the length tedious, some of the dialogue eye-rolling and some of the digital effects lacking (the digital ship's digital wake seemed puny) when "Titanic" first came out. But those quibbles fade with time.

Name: Rene Rodriguez
All Critics Reviews: Here is a rare opportunity to return to something you once loved, and discover it still holds up, no apologies necessary.

Name: Scott A. Mantz
All Critics Reviews: Still a spectacular cinematic experience that, if nothing else, will remind moviegoers why they fell in love with it in the first place.

Name: Ed Gibbs
All Critics Reviews: A modern-day take on the classic Hollywood romance, delivered with the kind of panache long thought lost to the sands of time, that proves essentially timeless.

Name: Paul Byrnes
All Critics Reviews: Turns out hubris and greed float, like sorrow.

Name: Laura Clifford
All Critics Reviews: The unprecedented special effects...never overpower the fictional love story and historical human tragedy which are presented. It's not only awe-inspiring, it's surprisingly moving.

Name: JimmyO
All Critics Reviews: As dreadful as another post conversion of a blockbuster may sound, this is as good as it gets

Name: Sandie Angulo Chen
All Critics Reviews: Great movie, but not appropriate for all kids.

Name: Tim Brayton
All Critics Reviews: Exactly what it says on the label: a deliciously overwrought melodramatic love story, capped off with one of the greatest special effects achievements of the 1990s.

Name: Josh Larsen
All Critics Reviews: Feeling dispassionate about Titanic is a bit like being stranded alone on the North Atlantic.

Name: Louise Keller
All Critics Reviews: Extravagant, exhilarating, devastating, poetic, romantic and totally unforgettable, Titanic is an extraordinary achievement in film making, where technology astounds, yet the human story shines even brighter

Name: Andrew L. Urban
All Critics Reviews: You will walk out of Titanic not talking about budget or running time, but of its enormous emotive power, big as the engines of the ship itself, determined as its giant propellers to gouge into your heart, and as lasting as the love story that propels it.

Name: David Edelstein
All Critics Reviews: Now it can be told: The Titanic went down because of two distracting smoochers on the poop deck.

Name: Todd McCarthy
All Critics Reviews: In the end, Cameron's monumental epic still prises open the tear ducts.

Name: Desson Thomson
All Critics Reviews: A spectacular demonstration of what modern technology can contribute to dramatic storytelling.

Name: Stephen Hunter
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a good, often stunning movie caught in a three-and-a-half hour drift.

Name: David Ansen
All Critics Reviews: This is Cameron at his best.

Name: Emanuel Levy
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is big, bold, touchingly uncynical filmmaking.

Name: Gary Brown
All Critics Reviews: Cameron skillfully applies sophisticated special effects to classic American storytelling, resulting in a winning combination of a tale that's modern and old-fashioned, delivering the goods expected of the disaster genre.

Name: Andrew Sarris
All Critics Reviews: There is nothing to dislike about this film.

Name: Steven D. Greydanus
All Critics Reviews: Titanic runs well enough in the backstretch of intrigue and contrivance to cross the finish line well ahead of all but a few of the screen's superspectacles in this century.

Name: Geoff Andrew
All Critics Reviews: Perhaps the most melancholy thing about Titanic is its celebration of romantic ideals to the exclusion of such self-denying virtues as honor, duty, and heroism.

Name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
All Critics Reviews: Cost: well over $200m. Disregarding the ethics of such expenditure on a film, this unprecedented extravagance has not resulted in sophisticated or even very satisfying storytelling.

Name: Douglas Pratt
All Critics Reviews: A brilliantly designed, but emotionally shallow romance set during the infamous sinking of the luxury liner in 1912.

Name: Eric Henderson
All Critics Reviews: A grand and classy production.

Name: Robin Clifford
All Critics Reviews: It's something of an ingenuous revision of the standard disaster movie.

Name: Sky Staff
All Critics Reviews: An enormous technical achievement with a wonderfully big heart.

Name: Jeffrey Overstreet
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is some big movie.

Name: Martin Scribbs
All Critics Reviews: The spectacle of the ship will enchant you, and the tragedy of the victims will haunt you for many days after you've seen it.

Name: Dragan Antulov
All Critics Reviews: Abyss-mal.

Name: Jeanne Aufmuth
All Critics Reviews: Rose and Jack are burdened with simplistic characterisation and atrocious dialogue.

Name: Nick Davis
All Critics Reviews: The plot before the collision is almost dispensable, but from that moment on, it is absolutely riveting.

Name: Chris Gore
All Critics Reviews: Yes, Jack Dawson and Rose DeWitt Bukater are flimsyish characters, but DiCaprio and Winslet still have the formidable challenge as actors to gauge the levels of their performances against the galvanizing visual and technotronic aspects of the film.

Name: Margaret A. McGurk
All Critics Reviews: The film is the best of the year.

Name: Kevin N. Laforest
All Critics Reviews: An old-fashioned epic, a brawny drama built on tragedy, adventure, romance, charismatic stars and jaw-dropping, high-tech special effects.

Name: Pablo Villa√ßa
All Critics Reviews: It lasts 3 hours, and I wasn't bored for a second.

Name: Rick Groen
All Critics Reviews: Quando eu sa do cinema no era apenas um espectador fascinado. Era um sobrevivente do Titanic.

Name: Peter Keough
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is awesome even when it's awful -- you can't take your eyes off the extraordinary thing.

Name: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat
All Critics Reviews: The film's long final phase is a harrowing series of sublime images of death and those about to die.

Name: Brandon Judell
All Critics Reviews: The finale is a special effects dazzler but those scenes pale in comparison to the dramatic and creative ways Cameron exalts the salvific power of love.

Name: Almar Haflidason
All Critics Reviews: If when you see this film, you believe it's credible, God bless you and your unfortunate offspring with their damaged gene pool.

Name: Andrew Howe
All Critics Reviews: Despite its failings it's hard not to become swept up in the sheer grandeur of Titanic.

Name: James Kendrick
All Critics Reviews: The incredible finale more than makes up for its other crimes.

Name: Kenneth Turan
All Critics Reviews: In his brilliant, monumental film Titanic, one of the most popular and beloved Hollywood movies of the past 50 years, James Cameron revisited that night in all its horror and glory.

Name: Robert Roten
All Critics Reviews: A hackneyed, completely derivative copy of old Hollywood romances, a movie that reeks of phoniness and lacks even minimal originality.

Name: Barbara Shulgasser
All Critics Reviews: This is a fine example of Hollywood filmmaking. This is a studio film in the best sense of the word.

Name: Maitland McDonagh
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is awash in truncated subplots.

Name: Jay Carr
All Critics Reviews: The drama is cliched, if competently effective, but Cameron's dissolves from the Titanic's rusted hulk to her brand spanking new decks are breathtaking, even poetic.

Name: Jeff Vice
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is big-budget spectacle and director Cameron brings it off with high-tech bravura, placing us aboard the ship in real time.

Name: Edward Johnson-Ott
All Critics Reviews: Kudos to stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, who make an appealing onscreen couple.

Name: Mike Clark
All Critics Reviews: Cameron has crafted an epic that triumphs.

Name: Urban Cinefile Critics
All Critics Reviews: Credit Cameron for locating that latitude-longitude spot where haunting loss intersects with sheer cinematic braggadocio. His movie may not be perfect, but visually and viscerally, it pretty well is.

Name: James Berardinelli
All Critics Reviews: An overwhelming cinematic experience which stuns, moves and entertains.

Name: Joe Baltake
All Critics Reviews: You don't just watch Titanic, you experience it.

Name: Marc Savlov
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a terrific balance of realism and romanticism.

Name: John Hartl
All Critics Reviews: It's still by far and away a grand, gorgeous, breathtaking spectacle.

Name: Stephanie Zacharek
All Critics Reviews: No other film has made the horror of the ship's sinking so palpable, and none other has dared to dramatize the night of the living dead that followed after it sank beneath the North Atlantic.

Name: Jonathan Rosenbaum
All Critics Reviews: Glub glub glub.

Name: Dennis Schwartz
All Critics Reviews: All things considered, Titanic is old-fashioned epic filmmaking that carries a wallop.

Name: David Sterritt
All Critics Reviews: An unconscionable disaster...

Name: Roger Ebert
All Critics Reviews: But what's most impressive about Titanic is the evidence it shows of new maturity in Cameron's filmmaking priorities.

Name: Michael Wilmington
All Critics Reviews: James Cameron's 194-minute, $200 million film of the tragic voyage is in the tradition of the great Hollywood epics. It is flawlessly crafted, intelligently constructed, strongly acted and spellbinding.

Name: MaryAnn Johanson
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a film that sweeps us away into a world of spectacle, beauty and excitement.

Name: Ed Kelleher
All Critics Reviews: Watching the film again, it suddenly struck me with the force of a pop-culture hurricane: Titanic is all about Rose. It is Rose's personal journey. This hardly ever happens in films...

Name: Owen Gleiberman
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a remarkable achievement.

Name: Janet Maslin
All Critics Reviews: A lush and terrifying spectacle of romantic doom.

Name: Nell Minow
All Critics Reviews: Cameron succeeds magically in linking his film's young lovers, played enchantingly by Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet.

Name: Bruce Kirkland
All Critics Reviews: Who'd have thought that the most expensive film ever made could also be good cinema?

Name: Carlo Cavagna
All Critics Reviews: The movie raises important questions about choices faced by the characters.

Name: Jack Garner
All Critics Reviews: James Cameron has made a miracle movie that delivers big-time.

Name: Marty Mapes
All Critics Reviews: The genius of Titanic does not lie in the story itself. It lies in how the story is told.

Name: Matt Easterbrook
All Critics Reviews: You've never seen a film of more stunning visual splendor.

Name: Madeleine Williams
All Critics Reviews: The melodramatic love story is the perfect foreground for the sinking of the largest passenger ship in history.

Name: Adam Smith
All Critics Reviews: Forgive me if I gush too much, for I have just come back from seeing one of the five best films ever made.

Name: Mike McGranaghan
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is one of his best, and raises the bar yet again.

Name: Michael Dequina
All Critics Reviews: James Cameron has gone and delivered a spectacular, moving, utterly engrossing three-and-a-bit hour epic.

Name: Ted Prigge
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is not a perfect film, but it is a great film nonetheless.

Name: Widgett Walls
All Critics Reviews: This absorbing, moving cinematic spectacle not only floats, it soars.

Name: David Keyes
All Critics Reviews: A wonderful masterpiece of a film.

Name: Rob Blackwelder
All Critics Reviews: To take the space to try to convey to you all of the things that Cameron did right with this film would basically wipe out my alloted server storage.

Name: Ian Mantgani
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is one of those flawless, spellbinding epics that we all know and love.

Name: Frank Ochieng
All Critics Reviews: It is opulent, daring, detailed, vastly over-priced and incomparable.

Name: Shane Burridge
All Critics Reviews: The best film of its genre ever made.

Name: Mark R. Leeper
All Critics Reviews: What Cameron does is essentially give us a history lesson in an empowering, emphatic, entertaining way. This extraordinary flick feels like a big event with a litany of emblematic scope and impressive visual vitality.

Name: David N. Butterworth
All Critics Reviews: This man makes the bluest looking movies around

Name: Jeff Millar
All Critics Reviews: This is a big film with a lot to like as well as a lot to not.

Name: Scott Renshaw
All Critics Reviews: Time skips by quickly, and there are more than a few decent supporting performances to enjoy.

Name: Kristian M. Lin
All Critics Reviews: Titanic will give you your money's worth.

Name: Tom Keogh
All Critics Reviews: May be the year's most effective and consistently entertaining love story.

Name: Peter Rainer
All Critics Reviews: The movie's human elements are entirely stale, however appealingly packaged.

Name: Christopher Null
All Critics Reviews: The would-be emotional centerpiece of his three-hours-plus adventure flick is the most juvenile romantic tale of 1997.

Name: Harvey S. Karten
All Critics Reviews: There's a lot to like here.

Name: Steve Rhodes
All Critics Reviews: Whatever it's pigeon-holed as, you're going to love the movie.

Name: Peter Brunette
All Critics Reviews: It is perhaps the best example in 1997 of a film which is pure, simple melodrama.

Name: Bryant Frazer
All Critics Reviews: It is filmmaking at its best.

Name: Dan Jardine
All Critics Reviews: The disaster is definitely worth the wait.

Name: Cynthia Fuchs
All Critics Reviews: It's clear that Titanic will be a technophile's delight.

Name: Joseph McBride
All Critics Reviews: Titanic is a great, soft-hearted traditional epic.

Name: Stanley Kauffmann
All Critics Reviews: This disaster-action-adventure-romance flick combines epic aspiration with cartoonish simplicity, with no qualms about going for the popular jugular, jerking tears and cheers with equal obviousness.

Name: Robert Horton
All Critics Reviews: Like a David Lean film, it is an intimate epic with a moving and resonant love story at its core.

Name: Susan Stark
All Critics Reviews: Bursting through gaps in the hull, rushing down corridors, licking at rooms, triumphing over great ballrooms and tiny closets, down stairways and into elevators, the sea, in the hands of Cameron and his technical associates, becomes hungry, vindictive.

Name: Mick LaSalle
All Critics Reviews: Like it or hate it, Titanic lives and breathes as a piece of pure cinema.

Name: Richard Corliss
All Critics Reviews: As spectacle, Titanic sets a new standard; as romantic drama, it's substandard.

Name: Scott Nash
All Critics Reviews: The last hour of Titanic is huge and staggering, but there's no horror in it.
